author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

I disagree. I think that

> PsychoJL is a module for writing psychology and psychophysics experiments. The general framework and style is inspired by PsychoPy, but there has been no collaboration with the authors of PsychoPy.

Does not warrant including JL in the name PsychoJL.jl. Julia and Python have different package naming conventions. Most notably in this case, all Julia names are already suffixed by .jl. 

Given the description of the repo is

> API for writing Psychology Experiments

I would recommend the name PsychologyExperiments.jl because that way anyone who sees the package name immediately knows that it is a Julia package for physiology experiments (whereas, for example, if it is named PsychoJL.jl, someone seeing the name wouldn't know if it is for experiments or if it is targeted at modeling psychological states directly, at embedding human psychology in AI, or supporting academic instruction in psychology, etc.). To get a more accurate picture one would still need to read the manual, but it's nice to give folks as much as possible to wrkr off of at a glance.

Iff psychophysics is central to the package and is not a type of psychology, then it would imo make sense to abbreviate to PsychoExperiments.jl.
Fair enough. Not my call, ultimately :-)

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
